cinder/cmd/manage.py.message:
With python-cinderclient, we've tried to be consistent (and failed at times) with making sure command line arguments use - instead of _. We should keep that consistency here.

Because of that, and because this is an existing argument that has a small potential to break someone's scripts by changing it now, we should not change the arg name.

The better approach in this situation I think is to do:

@args('cluster-name', dest='cluster_name', ...)

Could you try that and see if it works?

Is this an actual issue though? It is passed in positionaly, so it should be fine if the name defined in the decorator is different than the name we give the method parameter.

> Is this an actual issue though?

With the existing implementation:

    @args('cluster-name', type=str, ...)

I get the following error [0]:

    oslo_config.cfg.NoSuchOptError: no such option cluster_name in group [DEFAULT]

> @args('cluster-name', dest='cluster_name', ...)
> Could you try that and see if it works?

I tried, but then I got the following error [1]:

    ValueError: dest supplied twice for positional argument

I guess it only works for double-dash parameters (e.g. --cluster-name).

[0] http://paste.openstack.org/show/798095/
[1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/798096/

Well, the root cause of the problem is described in the LP Bug #1894381:

> The problem is that option name registed in CONF is cluster-name, but arg in action_func is cluster_name,

So we might need to investigate it instead.

Apparently I forgot back then to test it and that positional arguments don't get dash to underscore replacement treatment.

I think the change is acceptable, after all it's a positional argument and won't change any scripts calling this CLI command.

If we just don't want the help command output to change from

  usage: cinder-manage cluster remove [-h] [--recursive] binary cluster-name

to

  usage: cinder-manage cluster remove [-h] [--recursive] binary cluster_name

We can add parameter `metavar='cluser-name'` and it will maintain the help output.

    @args('cluster_name', metavar='cluster-name', type=str,
          help='Cluster to delete.')

Though I like Lucio's idea about changing the args decorator.

At this point, the argument is added as 'cluster-name' instead of 'cluster_name'. That causes oslo_config.cfg.NoSuchOptError when trying to retrieve 'cluster_name' argument.

So we need to sanitize the argument with get_arg_string before adding it to the parser.

Maybe in the definition of the `args` decorator?

It worked when I replaced the content of args with the sanitized string:
http://paste.openstack.org/show/798200/

Though I think it's not very smart to modify its contents right here. We could add it in the `args` decorator definition at L126, but it still requires replacing tuples (which semantically means "do not modify me", so it sounds wrong).
Thks, I agree with the idea about changing args decorator, which keep consistency that CLI arguments use dash. Let me try to fix it.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I'm curious to know what would be the motivation to use local memcached instead of clustered one ? (maybe stability issue I guess)

If we use only local one then it means that we expect more often cache miss until the client hit the all controller nodes. So from perspective of performance it doesn't sound like optimal option.

Thanks for clarification.

I'm interested in this because I recently implemented general memcached caching in authtoken middleware and caching in keystone as per deprecation message from authtoken middleware and discussion about the advantage of caching in keystone for quicker token verification...

It really depends on the service. The idea is that at least for nova metadata we switch to source routing (https://review.opendev.org/759052) so we always hit the same metadata worker.
The high-level idea is to use the localhost one on controller nodes (or on roles where the role memcached is installed and configured) and retain the internal_api memcached triplet for computes and roles which do not have it.

The rationale is that:
a) using localhost is faster and we should not rely on remote memcached being hot (in case we can improve the source lb selection for services)
b) if a controller node goes down we behave better, since py-memcached has horrible "node is gone" detection and constantly times out when a service is down.

There has been a rather long internal thread about this I can forward you the details if you want.

In any case these are just preparation patches to give us the option of changing the memcached setup a little, the real switch will happen in other reviews once we get to it and we'll need to test those more before confirming.

deployment/memcached/memcached-container.message:
IIRC we always have ::1 enabled in overcloud nodes, even if we disable IPv6 by the KernelDisableIPv6 parameter, so it might be better to use ::1 instead of 127.0.0.1 .

Another option would be to use MemcachedNetwork to check which IP stack it should use, as is done in redis deployment templates.

We're kind of trying to get away from users having to specify RedisIPv6 and the likes as it is error prone and we should do better/simpler in general.

In this case I believe it is more likely that 127.0.0.1 always exists rather than ::1 so it seems the safer option in general?

I didn't intend to add a new parameter like MemcachedIPv6 but check the ip version assigned to MemcachedNetwork as we do for redis with RedisNetwork.

The availability of 127.0.0.1 might depend on the way how we implemente IPv6 only deployment, but since I don't see any implementation implying that 127.0.0.1 is disabled, I think we are good to use 127.0.0.1 .
Ah I see now, thanks. That makes sense I'll amend it so we're consistent across services

manifests/site/test-site/metadata.yaml.message:
This path actually links to the repository defined as the PrimaryPhaseRepository in metadata.yaml [0]. Since we haven't defined one yet, airshipctl is choosing a repository named "primary" as the default option.

Since this repo is openstack-helm-deployments, and we only want to borrow phases from airshipctl, openstack-helm-deployments is really our primary repository. We want the path to look like:

  path: manifests/site/test-site/phases

In order to make that work, we just need to use the relative path, ../airshipctl, when we patch the phases we borrow from airshipctl [1]. There aren't any Kustomize patches in master yet, but this [2] is what we need to do to accomplish that in this change.

[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm-deployments/src/branch/master/manifests/site/test-site/metadata.yaml

[1] https://opendev.org/airship/airshipctl/src/branch/master/manifests/phases/phases.yaml

[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/756401/38/manifests/site/test-site/phases/patch_phases.yaml

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/api/controll.message:
This would be better named is_rook_ceph_monitor_deployed().

So this calls the kubernetes API to look for specific pods. But the Rook app will not be running until all the hosts are provisioned and unlocked.

I think this should be gated by the presence of controller has a rook label present: ceph-mon-placement=enabled.

Are we allowing a storage personality to be added for Rook? Or only workers with OSDs?

Seem like logic should be: if there is not a rook label on the controller(s) and there is a storage backend present, then allow a storage personality to be added

This is also for remove restriction for multi-node with storage node case, after migration, lock/unlock storage node. After last time review, for storage node migration should go through process, lock, reinstall and change personality to worker, this check could be removed.

This is trying to avoid the scenario in LP1851287.  I don't think we can just skip this for Rook. 

Have you considered still using the host-stor-add CLI to identify OSDs on workers. then have the rook plugin generate the correct overrides using the persistent device names?

If you did that then this check would still be valid after changing check_recovery_in_progress() to get the health information

I don't think this check is needed if we  only allow the storage personality to be added when a Ceph storage backend is present (i.e. bare metal install). Then the corollary would that we prevent applying the rook app if the Ceph storage backend is present

This check is for multi node deployed system  with storage node, then migration to rook. 

As last time review meeting for migration, for multi node migration, change process to host delete, and reinstall with personality change. So this check could be removed.

eek, I do understand this but are we sure it's the best verification ? Wouldn't it be better to look whether it's a private class or not ?
At least, maybe looking at the underscore ?

Yup, but how can we be sure it won't change later in years, like by adding new public methods that would have not this prefix ?

Of course, the python-libvirt API is public so hopefully new methods not having a "vir" prefix should be only supported by a major release, but maybe we should document it, or verifying that the other private classes are just 'libvirtException' and just provide an exception if not ?

Yes, as documented by danpb in the bug we only care about the public vir* classes in the libvirt module so while odd this is enough:

this change the API but during ML discussion we agreed to fix it as bug not with microversion bump.

Note: this is special case of API change which need operators to change the permission level of users to make this change as no-impact. 

user without having the 'GET /project' permission in keystone and add valid project in flavor access:

-Before this change: able to set the flavor with *valid project*

-After this change: need to have GET /project permission first to add *valid project* (or say allowing them to continue the same what they used to do).

It is more like we are changing the API but changes can be no-impact if policy configuration is modified by operators. which is nothing but similar to a policy or config default value change. policy or config change does not need microversion but need deprecation warning phase so that we notify them and give time to avoid breaking their users.

Similar way, I suggest to add the deprecation warning here for one cycle and then do this change. That way we can notify operators about this needed-configuration-changes from their side in advance before actual break.

But I am open to know more opinion here.

Discussed this in today's IRC meeting. The conclusion seems to be to raise a warning in V and fix properly in W. We're doing this rather than a microversion because users shouldn't have to opt out of broken behavior. I'm not all that happy with this halfway solution. If the fix is important enough to warrant skipping a microversion, then we should fix it now and backport that fix. This might break some deployments where policy is misconfigured (afaict, this won't happen with the policy we ship), however, again, if this is important enough to skip a microversion for, it's important enough to deal with this headache. We can document things and resolve them as necessary. My 2c, anyway.

-1: Backup for the Ceph driver doesn't use the _transfer_data method in volume_utils, it uses the method _transfer_data method in cinder/backup/drivers/ceph.py, which also has the same check of b'', so this patch should also fix it there.

We cannot determine whether to write it to the destination based only on that. What if we are overwriting the contents of a volume (like in restore a backup to a volume) and the zeroes from the source volume are actual data that we need to have in the destination?

In that case we wouldn't be writing the right data (all those zeroes) and the destination would have whatever it had before instead.

I think we could only do it this way if the destination was a thin provisioned volume, where empty chunks will return zeroes on read.

To detect sparse chunks using SCSI we would have to get the LBA status and see if it is Deallocated, Anchored, or Mapped, and for RBD I'm not sure how this could be done.

In my opinion, we cannot skip chunks so easily, this requires a more complete solution.

cinder/volume/volume_utils.py.message: We are no longer adding our handles in front of notes, please remove it.

-1: As mentioned in the Python docs [1] "If 0 bytes are returned, and size was not 0, this indicates end of file", and it should be true for sparse files as well.

Usually we get zeroes when we read empty portions of a sparse file/device.

You can easily confirm this with some python code:

  import os
  # Create sparse file
  f = open('test.txt', 'ab')
  f.truncate(1024000)
  f.close()

  print('Used blocks in disk are %s' % os.stat('test.txt').st_blocks)

  f = open('test.txt', 'rb')
  print(repr(f.read(10))
  
If we are talking about RBD, then it's probably a problem that needs to be fixed somewhere else...

For example in the os-brick code that has the actual read method [2], where we are returning b'' when we read beyond the length of the file.

Looking at the Python rbd/rados bindings for the read method [3] one thing that could be happening is getting fewer bytes than we requested [4] (maybe even zero?), which is accepted behavior for the Python read method [1]: "Fewer than size bytes may be returned if the operating system call returns fewer than size bytes."

But if that's the case, then it doesn't mean that we can skip that chunk, but that we have to retry it...

Can you provide steps to reproduce the issue with the RBD driver?  Because I don't think this is the solution.


[1]: https://docs.python.org/3/library/io.html#io.RawIOBase.read

[2]: https://github.com/openstack/os-brick/blob/165c8017e4e11f0f0e60a166cc1b399735eab29e/os_brick/initiator/linuxrbd.py#L179-L183

[3]: https://github.com/ceph/ceph/blob/ae4fd30ffc55faf9300dc6553aa4cb149a9663ab/src/pybind/rbd/rbd.pyx#L4271-L4315

[4]: https://github.com/ceph/ceph/blob/ae4fd30ffc55faf9300dc6553aa4cb149a9663ab/src/pybind/rbd/rbd.pyx#L4306-L4307

if the data we get is b'',that means we have reached end of source, it should be true for sparse files as well. 
if data is not b'', but all characters in the data are \x00, that means src maybe sparse files, so we need to read next chunk.

i think the os-brick is right, no need to fix.

-1: I don't think we should do this.  If we know that the source's `read` method is not properly implemented (it returns b'' when reading an empty chunk), how can we assume that it has actually moved the current position?

If the `read` method is actually failing this way, then we need to keep track of the position ourselves and use it to do the seek in both the source and the destination.
I've added the retry mechanism，and saved the source file before the location, easy to try to read again.

I'm not sure if it's a good idea to have default login/password instead of making them mandatory.

The user might feel inclined to use the default ones, which are hardcoded in the driver and therefore are too easy to guess.
It's up to you, but I recommend adding a note telling the users to change the credentials in production, so they won't blame you if an incident happens.
